maml:description.maml:para: Adds an IPv6 Reservation to an IPv6 prefix or scope.

The Add-DhcpServerv6Reservation cmdlet reserves a specified IPv6 address for the client identified by the specified Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) v6 unique identifier (ID) (DUID) and identity association ID (IAID).
Specifies the IPv6 prefix which identifies the scope in which the reservation is created.
Specifies the IPv6 address to be reserved for the client.
Specifies the DUID of the client.
Specifies the DHCPv6 IAID of a specific network interface of the client.
Specifies the name of the client. This parameter value can be the actual host name of the client or a name assigned to identify the reserved client on the DHCP server service.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the DNS name, or IPv4 or IPv6 address, of the target computer running the DHCP server service.
Specifies the description string for the IPv6 reservation being created.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the DUID of the client.
Specifies the DNS name, or IPv4 or IPv6 address, of the target computer running the DHCP server service.
Specifies the description string for the IPv6 reservation being created.
Specifies the DHCPv6 IAID of a specific network interface of the client.
Specifies the IPv6 address to be reserved for the client.
Specifies the name of the client. This parameter value can be the actual host name of the client or a name assigned to identify the reserved client on the DHCP server service.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.
Specifies the IPv6 prefix which identifies the scope in which the reservation is created.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

The Microsoft.Management.Infrastructure.CimInstance object is a wrapper class that displays Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) objects. The path after the pound sign (#) provides the namespace and class name for the underlying WMI object.

The Microsoft.Management.Infrastructure.CimInstance object is a wrapper class that displays Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) objects. The path after the pound sign (#) provides the namespace and class name for the underlying WMI object.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example reserves the specified IPv6 address for the specified ClientDuid and Iaid parameter values. After the reservation is added, the DHCP server service will assign only the specified IP address to the client request which contains the specified ClientDuid and Iaid parameter values.

command:example.maml:title: EXAMPLE 2
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Import-Csv –Path Reservations.csv | Add-DhcpServerv6Reservation -ComputerName dhcpserver.contoso.com

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example adds all of the reservations in the file named Reservations.csv to the DHCP server service running on the computer named dhcpserver.contoso.com. The Import-Csv cmdlet returns the objects with reservation fields and pipes the objects to this cmdlet, which adds these reservations to the DHCP server service. The file named Reservations.csv should contain the reservations in the following comma-separated values (CSV) format:

command:example.maml:title: Example 3
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $freeip = Get-DhcpServerv6FreeIPAddress -ComputerName dhcpserver.contoso.com -Prefix 2001:4898:7020:1020:: PS C:\> Add-DhcpServerv6Reservation -ComputerName dhcpserver.contoso.com -Prefix 2001:4898:7020:1020:: -IPAddress $freeip -ClientDuid 00-01-00-01-15-F9-7F-AB-F0-DE-F1-7A-00-5E -Iaid 234890455 -Description "Reservation for Printer"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example creates a reservation for the client identified by the specified client ID from any of the free IP address in the scope 2001:4898:7020:1020::. The Get-DhcpServerv6FreeIPAddress cmdlet fetches a free IP address in that scope, then this cmdlet reserves the IP address for the specified client ID.

command:example.maml:title: EXAMPLE 4
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-DhcpServerv6Lease -ComputerName dhcpserver.contoso.com -IPAddress 2001:4898:7020:1020::11 | Add-DhcpServerv6Reservation -ComputerName dhcpserver.contoso.com -Prefix 2001:4898:7020:1020::

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example converts one of the leases into a reservation. The Get-DhcpServerv6Lease cmdlet returns an IP address lease object and pipes the object to this cmdlet, which creates the reservation with the IP address, client DUID, and IAID in the lease object.

maml:description.maml:para: Returns the reserved IPv6 addresses on the Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) server service.
The Get-DhcpServerv6Reservation cmdlet returns the reserved IPv6 addresses and associated client information (DUID, IAID) from the Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) server service.
Specifies the IPv6 prefix of the DHCP server service from which the reservations are requested.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the DNS name, or IPv4 or IPv6 address, of the target computer running the DHCP server service.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Specifies the IPv6 addresses for which the reservation information is requested.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the DNS name, or IPv4 or IPv6 address, of the target computer running the DHCP server service.
Specifies the IPv6 addresses for which the reservation information is requested.
Specifies the IPv6 prefix of the DHCP server service from which the reservations are requested.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The Microsoft.Management.Infrastructure.CimInstance object is a wrapper class that displays Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) objects. The path after the pound sign (#) provides the namespace and class name for the underlying WMI object.

The Microsoft.Management.Infrastructure.CimInstance object is a wrapper class that displays Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) objects. The path after the pound sign (#) provides the namespace and class name for the underlying WMI object.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example gets the information for all of the reserved IPv6 addresses in the specified DHCPv6 scope.
This example gets the information for a specified reserved IPv6 address on the DHCP server service running on the computer named dhcpserver.contoso.com.

This example gets all of the reserved IP addresses from all of the DHCPv6 scopes on the DHCP server service running on the computer named dhcpserver.contoso.com. The Get-DhcpServerv6Scope cmdlet returns all of the scope objects and pipes the objects into this cmdlet, which gets the reservations from each of the scopes passed through the pipeline.

maml:description.maml:para: Deletes one or more IPv6 reservations from the specified scope.

The Remove-DhcpServerv6Reservation cmdlet deletes one or more IPv6 reservations from the specified scope. If the Prefix parameter is specified, then all of the reservations from the scope will be removed. If the IPAddress parameter is specified, then one or more specified reservations are deleted.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the DNS name, or IPv4 or IPv6 address, of the target computer running the Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) server service.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Specifies one or more IPv6 addresses of the reservations being deleted.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Specifies the IPv6 subnet prefix of the scope from which one or more reservations are being deleted.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example deletes the reservation for the specified IPv6 addresses.
This example deletes all of the reservations from the specified IPv6 scope.

This example deletes all of the reserved IP addresses from all of the DHCPv6 scopes on the DHCP server service running on the computer named dhcpserver.contoso.com. The Get-DhcpServerv6Scope cmdlet returns all of the scope objects and pipes the objects into this cmdlet, which deletes the reservations from each of the scopes passed through the pipeline.

maml:description.maml:para: Modifies the properties of the specified IPv6 reservation.
The Set-DhcpServerv6Reservation cmdlet modifies the properties of the specified IPv6 reservation.
Specifies the IPv6 address of the reservation being modified.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the DHCPv6 unique identifier (ID) to set for the reservation.
Specifies the DNS name, or IPv4 or IPv6 address, of the target computer running the Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) server service.
Specifies the description to set for the reservation.
Specifies the DHCPv6 interface ID (IAID) to set for the reservation.
Specifies the name to set for the reservation.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

command:example.maml:title: EXAMPLE 1
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Set-DhcpServerv6Reservation -ComputerName dhcpserver.contoso.com -IPAddress 2001:4898:7020:1020::5 -Description "Fourth Floor Printer" -Name printer.contoso.com

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example sets the name and description for an existing DHCPv6 reservation for IP address 2001:4898:7020:1020::5.
